page.title: 02HARESFIELD BEACON
page.content: This area is open grassland owned by the National Trust. Haresfield Beacon has one of the finest views from the South West edge of the Cotswold escarpment. It is a natuaral promontary fortification 700 feet above sea level. There was an early Iron Age settlement on the site and the Romans had a large camp here. In the 19th century, 3000 Roman coins were found here. To the South East is a topograph, a direction finder from where, on a clear day, it is possible to see across the Severn Vale to the Forest of Dean and even the Brecon Beacons in Wales. Randwick Woods are also owned by the National Trust. To the south of the escarpment, in the woods, is a long barrow which is now covered by trees, mainly larch and copper beech.
